   - HCT 27 -> 25.7 -> 24.4 (1U) -> 26 (1U) -> 27.5 -> 28
   - EKG: VPaced
   - Received Vit K IV
   - Renal: HD Line Placed,
   - Rheum: 1. Would change steroids to solumedrol 1000 mg IV Daily for 3
   days 2. Stop allopurinol indefinitely. 3. Agree with transfusion
   medicine consult for possible plasmapheresis.  4. F/u with anti-GBM and
   ANCA. 5. Repeat echocardiogram (TEE) to evaluate for current cardiac
   status/function, vegetations and possible CHF.
   - Derm: Nothing
   - Intubated, Aline placed, Dialysis Catheter Placed.
   - Bronchoscopy: Diffuse Bleeding
   - ECHO:The left atrium is moderately dilated. Left ventricular wall
   thickness, cavity size and regional/global systolic function are normal
   (LVEF >55%). [Intrinsic left ventricular systolic function is likely
   more depressed given the severity of valvular regurgitation.] Right
   ventricular chamber size is normal. with borderline normal free wall
   function. There is abnormal septal motion/position consistent with
   right ventricular pressure/volume overload. A bileaflet aortic valve
   prosthesis is present. The transaortic gradient is normal for this
   prosthesis. No masses or vegetations are seen on the aortic valve, but
   cannot be fully excluded due to suboptimal image quality. Trace aortic
   regurgitation is seen. [The amount of regurgitation present is normal
   for this prosthetic aortic valve.] The mitral valve leaflets are
   moderately thickened. No masses or vegetations are seen on the mitral
   valve, but cannot be fully excluded due to suboptimal image quality. An
   eccentric, posteriorly directed jet of moderate (2+) mitral
   regurgitation is seen. No masses or vegetations are seen on the
   tricuspid valve, but cannot be fully excluded due to suboptimal image
   quality. Moderate [2+] tricuspid regurgitation is seen. There is
   moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no
   pericardial effusion. If clinically suggested, the absence of a
   vegetation by 2D echocardiography does not exclude endocarditis,
   especially on a bileaflet aortic valve. Compared with the prior study
   (images reviewed) of [**2128-1-8**], the severity of mitral and tricuspid
   regurgitation has increased. The right ventricular function may be
   slighlty less vigorous.
   - ID: Fine to change to Cefepime/Vancomycin. From Cefazolin.
   - Path: Nothing

   No Known Drug Allergies

   Fluid analysis / Other labs: BAL - no PMNs or bacteria seen on Gram
   stain.
   Imaging: Only line placement CXR today.
   Microbiology: No growth yet. C. difficile negative.
   Assessment and Plan
   76M with CAD s/p CABG, s/p mechanical AVR, Afib; currently hospitalized
   for MSSA endocarditis with complications of ARF and apparent AIN, CHB
   and torsades, and leukocytoclastic vasculitis on skin biopsy, now
   transferred to MICU with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and
   hemoptysis concerning for DAH.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure and hemoptysis.  Concerning for DAH
   given CXR findings as well.  Could also be pulmonary edema with
   hemorrhage due to anticoagulation, HAP with hemorrhage, development of
   ARDS with bleeding for other reasons or from other source.  DAH most
   concerning, particularly in light of prior ARF (?renal manifestations),
   vasculitic rash, elevated ESR.  [**Doctor First Name 1205**] negative, ANCA negative
   - Intubate now (larger tube preferred).
   - Bronchoscopy today; looking for progressive or continued blood with
   subsequent BALs.
   - Run recent medication exposures for possible culprits of DAH.
   - Initiate workup for and ?treatment for anti-GBM disease.  Send
   anti-GBM.  ?future renal biopsy.
   - Consult rheumatology and pathology/pheresis.
   - Will increase steroids to 125 mg Q6h, ?further increase if rec by
   rheum.
   - Will discuss cyclophosphamide with rheumatology.
   - ?pheresis today given concern for anti-GBM disease.  Will plan on
   line placement in anticipation of this and/or hemodialysis in near
   future.
   - Broad spectrum treatment for HAP and send sputum culture.  Will
   discuss with ID re: appropriate regimen (vanc plus beta lactam, ?still
   need to continue cefazolin).
   - Hold heparin, will not give protamine at this time.  WIll given
   vitamin K IV.
   #. Endocarditis: Based on Duke Criteria (1 Major, 3 minor).  High grade
   MSSA bacteremia. Per ID, antibiotics for planned 8 week course.
   Switched from Nafcillin/Rifampin to Vancomycin [**1-17**] due to AIN.  Now on
   Cefazolin since [**1-22**] instead of Vanc as better for MSSA with increased
   dosing [**1-25**].
   - Repeat blood cultures.
   - Will continue cefazolin for now, but given would like to treat for
   HAP, will discuss appropriate regimen.
   # Atrial fibrillation/complete heart block. History this admission of
   CHB (as well as torsades, thought due to FQs), now s/p screw-in
   pacemaker.
   - Hold heparin as above.
   - EP following - plan for 2 months of this pacer before likely
   permament pacer.
   #. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: Cr 1.5 on presentation; trending up
   now 3.4. Thought to be AIN due to Nafcillin.  Now unclear if this is
   truly manifestation of systemic vasculitis or anti-GBM disease.  Has
   had microscopic hematuria in recent past.
   - Resend urine.
   - f/u renal recs, discuss thoughts re: renal manifestation as above.
   - renally dose meds.
   - Change steroid to IV solumedrol.
   - diuresis likely when stabilized, vs. proceeding with HD.
   - ?future renal biopsy.
   # Anemia: Guaiac + stools this admission and have nuclear scan
   (negative).  Now with pulmonary hemorrhage likely.
   - recheck Hct Q8-Q12.
   - Consented for blood products.
   - H2 blocker given some concern that PPI could be causing AIN.
   # CAD.  s/p CABG and with DES x3 in one graft.
   - Continue statin.
   - Hold ASA for now, knowing high risk with DES.  Minimize time off ASA.
   - Holding ACE in the setting of renal failure.
   - Holding BB for now.
   # Leukoclastic vasculitis.  Thought due to Nafcillin or IE. Improving
   overall.  ?Could be related to systemic disease causing DAH.
   - will discuss with derm re: any relation to DAH.
   - steroids as above.
   #. s/p AVR (St. [**Male First Name (un) 6198**]).  Endocarditis as above.
   - As above, holding heparin.
   - CT surgery consult if clinical condition worsens and concerning for
   abscess.
   #. Hypertension.
   - Holding antiHTNs in setting of bleeding as above.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, TF recs.
   # Prophylaxis: boots, H2B
   # Access: PICC
   # Communication: Communication: wife: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11266**]; [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 11365**]
   (daughter and nurse) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11366**] - need to verify who is HCP.
   # Code:  Full (discussed with patient and family)
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, prior mechanical aortic valve replacement, and atrial fibrillation, who is currently hospitalized for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) endocarditis with complications of acute renal failure (ARF), acute interstitial nephritis (AIN), and leukocytoclastic vasculitis. The patient has been intubated due to hypoxemic respiratory failure and hemoptysis, and is suspected to have diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). The patient's condition is complex and multifaceted, with several potential medical complications arising from his underlying conditions and treatment.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Diffuse Alveolar Hemorrhage (DAH): The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure and hemoptysis are concerning for DAH, which could be caused by various factors, including anticoagulation, hemorrhagic pneumonia, or vasculitis.
2. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's renal function is deteriorating, and he may require hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis in the near future.
3. Atrial Fibrillation/Complete Heart Block: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and complete heart block, which may require further management and treatment.
4. Endocarditis: The patient has MSSA endocarditis, which may require a prolonged course of antibiotics and careful monitoring for complications.
5. Leukocytoclastic Vasculitis: The patient has leukocytoclastic vasculitis, which may be related to his underlying systemic disease or medication exposure.
6. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's respiratory failure and hemoptysis may be due to pulmonary edema, which could be caused by various factors, including anticoagulation, cardiac failure, or vasculitis.
7. Hemorrhagic Pneumonia: The patient's hemoptysis may be due to hemorrhagic pneumonia, which could be caused by various factors, including bacterial or fungal infection.
8. Anti-GBM Disease: The patient's renal failure and vasculitis may be related to anti-GBM disease, which could require further evaluation and treatment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and hemodynamic stability closely.
2. Consider further imaging studies, such as a computed tomography (CT) scan or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), to evaluate for DAH or other pulmonary complications.
3. Consult with cardiology and infectious disease specialists to further evaluate and manage the patient's endocarditis and respiratory failure.
4. Consider plasmapheresis or other immunosuppressive therapies to treat the patient's vasculitis and potential anti-GBM disease.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and consider hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis if necessary.
6. Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation and complete heart block with anticoagulation and other therapies as necessary.

   76M with CAD s/p CABG, s/p mechanical AVR, Afib; currently hospitalized
   for MSSA endocarditis with complications of ARF and apparent AIN, CHB
   and torsades, and leukocytoclastic vasculitis on skin biopsy, now
   transferred to MICU with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and
   hemoptysis concerning for DAH.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure and hemoptysis.  Concerning for DAH
   given CXR findings as well.  Could also be pulmonary edema with
   hemorrhage due to anticoagulation, HAP with hemorrhage, development of
   ARDS with bleeding for other reasons or from other source.  DAH most
   concerning, particularly in light of prior ARF (?renal manifestations),
   vasculitic rash, elevated ESR.  [**Doctor First Name 1205**] negative, ANCA negative
   - Intubate now (larger tube preferred).
   - Bronchoscopy today; looking for progressive or continued blood with
   subsequent BALs.
   - Run recent medication exposures for possible culprits of DAH.
   - Initiate workup for and ?treatment for anti-GBM disease.  Send
   anti-GBM.  ?future renal biopsy.
   - Consult rheumatology and pathology/pheresis.
   - Will increase steroids to 125 mg Q6h, ?further increase if rec by
   rheum.
   - Will discuss cyclophosphamide with rheumatology.
   - ?pheresis today given concern for anti-GBM disease.  Will plan on
   line placement in anticipation of this and/or hemodialysis in near
   future.
   - Broad spectrum treatment for HAP and send sputum culture.  Will
   discuss with ID re: appropriate regimen (vanc plus beta lactam, ?still
   need to continue cefazolin).
   - Hold heparin, will not give protamine at this time.  WIll given
   vitamin K IV.
   #. Endocarditis: Based on Duke Criteria (1 Major, 3 minor).  High grade
   MSSA bacteremia. Per ID, antibiotics for planned 8 week course.
   Switched from Nafcillin/Rifampin to Vancomycin [**1-17**] due to AIN.  Now on
   Cefazolin since [**1-22**] instead of Vanc as better for MSSA with increased
   dosing [**1-25**].
   - Repeat blood cultures.
   - Will continue cefazolin for now, but given would like to treat for
   HAP, will discuss appropriate regimen.
   # Atrial fibrillation/complete heart block. History this admission of
   CHB (as well as torsades, thought due to FQs), now s/p screw-in
   pacemaker.
   - Hold heparin as above.
   - EP following - plan for 2 months of this pacer before likely
   permament pacer.
   #. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: Cr 1.5 on presentation; trending up
   now 3.4. Thought to be AIN due to Nafcillin.  Now unclear if this is
   truly manifestation of systemic vasculitis or anti-GBM disease.  Has
   had microscopic hematuria in recent past.
   - Resend urine.

   - renally dose meds.
   - Change steroid to IV solumedrol.
   - diuresis likely when stabilized, vs. proceeding with HD.
   - ?future renal biopsy.
   # Anemia: Guaiac + stools this admission and have nuclear scan
   (negative).  Now with pulmonary hemorrhage likely.
   - recheck Hct Q8-Q12.
   - Consented for blood products.
   - H2 blocker given some concern that PPI could be causing AIN.
   # CAD.  s/p CABG and with DES x3 in one graft.
   - Continue statin.
   - Hold ASA for now, knowing high risk with DES.  Minimize time off ASA.
   - Holding ACE in the setting of renal failure.
   - Holding BB for now.
   # Leukoclastic vasculitis.  Thought due to Nafcillin or IE. Improving
   overall.  ?Could be related to systemic disease causing DAH.
   - will discuss with derm re: any relation to DAH.
   - steroids as above.
   #. s/p AVR (St. [**Male First Name (un) 6198**]).  Endocarditis as above.
   - As above, holding heparin.
   - CT surgery consult if clinical condition worsens and concerning for
   abscess.
   #. Hypertension.
   - Holding antiHTNs in setting of bleeding as above.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, mechanical aortic valve replacement, atrial fibrillation, and chronic renal failure. The patient was admitted to the hospital with suspected methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) endocarditis, acute kidney injury (AKI), and hemoptysis.

The patient's current condition is critical, with hypoxemic respiratory failure, hemoptysis, and acute on chronic renal failure. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's hemodynamic status is unstable, with a blood pressure of 95/50 mmHg and a heart rate of 75 beats per minute.

The patient's laboratory results are concerning, with a creatinine level of 3.4 mg/dL, a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 28 mg/dL, and a lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level of 61 mg/dL. The patient's white blood cell count is 13.4 x 10^9/L, and his platelet count is 88 x 10^9/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for atrial fibrillation, complete heart block, and torsades de pointes, which are likely related to his mechanical aortic valve replacement. The patient's current medications include warfarin, aspirin, and clopidogrel.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Pulmonary hemorrhage: The patient's hemoptysis and hypoxemic respiratory failure suggest a high risk of pulmonary hemorrhage.
2. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure and bilateral lung infiltrates on chest radiograph suggest a high risk of ARDS.
3. Septic shock: The patient's hypotension and tachycardia suggest a high risk of septic shock.
4. Cardiac tamponade: The patient's mechanical aortic valve replacement and atrial fibrillation suggest a high risk of cardiac tamponade.
5. Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure and electrolyte imbalance suggest a high risk of worsening renal failure.
6. Bleeding complications: The patient's coagulopathy and platelet count of 88 x 10^9/L suggest a high risk of bleeding complications.

Based on the patient's condition, I recommend the following:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and hemodynamic support.
2. Initiate antibiotics for suspected MSSA endocarditis.
3. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and heart rate closely, and consider vasopressors if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and electrolyte levels closely, and consider dialysis if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's coagulation status and platelet count closely, and consider transfusions if necessary.
6. Consider consulting with a cardiologist to evaluate the patient's cardiac status and potential complications.
7. Consider consulting with a nephrologist to evaluate the patient's renal function and potential complications.
8. Consider consulting with an intensivist to evaluate the patient's critical care needs.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical history and multiple potential complications. Close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   76M with CAD s/p CABG, s/p mechanical AVR, Afib; currently hospitalized
   for MSSA endocarditis with complications of ARF and apparent AIN, CHB
   and torsades, and leukocytoclastic dermatitis on skin biopsy, now
   transferred to MICU with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and
   hemoptysis concerning for DAH.
   Concern for immune mediated unifying diagnosis, versus coagulopathy and
   AIN with leukoclastic dermatitis. One critical piece of information may
   be whether immune cells cluster at arterioles in skin (vasculitis) or
   around capillaries (AIN and leukoclastic dermatitis proper). This will
   have important implications for treatment. Anti-GBM antibody test will
   be back tomorrow night at earliest per lab/pathologist. Rheumatology
   feel that this likely represents vasculitis and would like to broaden
   treatment to include plasmaphoresis then Cytoxan therapy. This will
   likely depend on whether pathology and Renal also feel that this is a
   vasculitis, not just AIN with associated rash after nafcillin or
   allopurinol. Goodpasture
s unlikely in view of presentation. ANCA is
   negative, but this is the case in about 20% of Wegener
s cases. No
   dysmorphic reds in urine, but this can sometimes be the case. Possible
   other vasculidites, but IgG, IgM and IgA staining in skin were not
   remarkable.
   # Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure and Possible Vasculitis
   Given findings on CXR, CVP, clinical presentation and bronchoscopy,
   likely secondary to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage and fluid overload. ESR
   is elevated, there is a pupruic macular rash and renal failure, all
   concerning for vasculitis, although there are other possibilities. [**Doctor First Name 1205**]
   and ANCA are negative and anti-GBM is pending. If we seek a unifying
   diagnosis, may be that anti-GBM is negative given skin process.
   Variability in antibody responsible may account for this, and general
   approaches and pathology may eventually be most helpful. Renal biopsy
   is possible (see below). Presently conditions of each organ stabilized
   on high dose steroids, also suggestive. Rheumatology raised Cytoxan
   treatment and plasmaphoresis, but we will need to discuss this further
   with Renal and Pathology.
   - Maintain intubation for now given lesser chance of hemorrhage without
   cough and management of respiratory parameters.
   - Repeat bronchoscopy today to remove thrombus plugging and examine
   again.
   - Await anti-GBM
   - Discuss renal biopsy
   - Continue to appreciate input of Rheumatology and Renal
   - Continue Solu-medrol
   - Consider Cytoxan and plasmapheresis with d/w Renal and Rheumatology
   - Broad spectrum treatment for HAP
 cefepime and vancomycin

   - Hold heparin, ASA
   # Hemoptysis and Coagulopathy
   Evidence, perhaps with purpuric rash, of coagulopathy, or potentially
   as a manifestation of vasculitis. For the former and possibly uremic
   platelets, anticoagulant therapy. In favor of the latter is unifying
   diagnosis and co-occurrence with renal disease and rash. See discussion
   above
   #. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure
   Cr 1.5 on presentation; up to 3.4, now 2.1 s/p CVVH. DDx includes AIN
   due to Nafcillin (also identical pathophysiology with concomitant rash
 see below).  Now unclear if this is truly manifestation of systemic
   vasculitis or drug reaction. White cells and eosinophils in urine
   consistent with either, although more classic of AIN.

   - Renally dose/CVVH dose meds.
   - Management as above, including IV Solu-medrol.
   - Possible renal biopsy tomorrow given that we are now holding

   # Leukoclastic Dermatitis
   Thought due to Nafcillin or allopurinol. Improving overall. See
   discussion above for relationship to unifying diagnosis.
   - Steroids as above.
   #. Bacteremia
   High-grade MSSA bacteremia and fulfils Duke Criteria (1 Major, 3 minor)
   for endocarditis. TTE did not reveal vegetations, but sensitivity
   likely low. Nonetheless, given AVR and concern, ID recommend
   antibiotics for a full 8 week course. Switched from Nafcillin/Rifampin

   - EP following - plan for 2 months of this pacer before likely
   permanent pacer.

   Now with pulmonary hemorrhage likely. If diffuse vasculitis or actually
   secondary to primary coagulopathy then need to maintain suspicion for
   other sites of blood loss, including GIT
   - Recheck Hct Q8-Q12.
   - Guaiac stool

   - H2 blocker given some concern that PPI could be causing AIN.
   # CAD

   anticoagulants. [**Month (only) 60**] be some concern for increased thrombosis risk in
   coming days, but have not choice given severity of presentation. We
   will need to revisit this when diagnosis is cleared and natural history
   of this presentation clearer.
   - Continue statin.

   - Holding BB for now.
   - No heparin for now

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), status post coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and mechanical aortic valve replacement (AVR). He is currently hospitalized with respiratory failure, hemorrhage, and renal failure, and is suspected to have endocarditis, vasculitis, and leukocytoclastic dermatitis.

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. He is intubated and receiving invasive ventilation, and has a PICC line, arterial line, and dialysis catheter in place. He is receiving high-dose steroids and antibiotics, and is being treated for potential vasculitis and coagulopathy.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH) and respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and there is a risk of further bleeding and respiratory failure.
2. Vasculitis and coagulopathy: The patient's vasculitis and coagulopathy can lead to further bleeding, organ dysfunction, and increased risk of thrombosis.
3. Endocarditis: The patient has a mechanical aortic valve replacement, and there is a risk of further endocarditis and valve dysfunction.
4. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and there is a risk of further kidney damage and dialysis dependence.
5. Leukocytoclastic dermatitis: The patient's skin lesions may worsen and spread, leading to further skin damage and increased risk of infection.
6. Bacteremia: The patient has a high-grade MSSA bacteremia, and there is a risk of further sepsis and organ dysfunction.
7. Atrial fibrillation and complete heart block: The patient's arrhythmias may worsen, leading to further cardiac complications.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further fatigue, weakness, and increased risk of bleeding.

The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications. His treatment plan should be individualized and adjusted as necessary to address his specific needs and condition.

   Assessment and Plan
   76M with CAD s/p CABG, s/p mechanical AVR, Afib; currently hospitalized
   for MSSA endocarditis with complications of ARF and apparent AIN, CHB
   and torsades, and leukocytoclastic dermatitis on skin biopsy, now
   transferred to MICU with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and
   hemoptysis concerning for DAH.
   Concern for immune mediated unifying diagnosis, versus coagulopathy and
   AIN with leukoclastic dermatitis. One critical piece of information may
   be whether immune cells cluster at arterioles in skin (vasculitis) or
   around capillaries (AIN and leukoclastic dermatitis proper). This will
   have important implications for treatment. Anti-GBM antibody test will
   be back tomorrow night at earliest per lab/pathologist. Rheumatology
   feel that this likely represents vasculitis and would like to broaden
   treatment to include plasmaphoresis then Cytoxan therapy. This will
   likely depend on whether pathology and Renal also feel that this is a
   vasculitis, not just AIN with associated rash after nafcillin or
   allopurinol. Goodpasture
s unlikely in view of presentation. ANCA is
   negative, but this is the case in about 20% of Wegener
s cases. No
   dysmorphic reds in urine, but this can sometimes be the case. Possible
   other vasculidites, but IgG, IgM and IgA staining in skin were not
   remarkable. This case will likely need pathophysiological rather than
   ontological approach.
   # Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure
   Concerning for DAH given CXR findings as well.  Could also be pulmonary
   edema with hemorrhage due to anticoagulation, HAP with hemorrhage,
   development of ARDS with bleeding for other reasons or from other
   source.  DAH most concerning, particularly in light of prior ARF
   (?renal manifestations), vasculitic rash, elevated ESR.  [**Doctor First Name 1205**] negative,
   ANCA negative

   rheum.

   line placement in anticipation of this and/or hemodialysis in near
   future.

   discuss with ID re: appropriate regimen (vanc plus beta lactam, ?still
   need to continue cefazolin).
   - Hold heparin, will not give protamine at this time.  WIll given
   vitamin K IV.
   # Hemoptysis
   Evidence, perhaps with purpuric rash, of coagulopathy, or potentially
   as a manifestation of vasculitis. For the former and possibly uremic
   platelets, anticoagulant therapy. In favor of the latter is unifying
   diagnosis and co-occurrence with renal disease and rash.

   Cr 1.5 on presentation; trending up now 3.4. Thought to be AIN due to
   Nafcillin.  Now unclear if this is truly manifestation of systemic
   vasculitis or anti-GBM disease.  Has had microscopic hematuria in

   to systemic disease causing DAH.

   #. Bacteremia
   High-grade MSSA bacteremia and fulfils Duke Criteria (1 Major, 3 minor)
   for endocarditis. TTE did not reveal vegetations, but sensitivity
   likely low. Nonetheless, given AVR and concern, ID recommend
   antibiotics for a full 8 week course. Switched from Nafcillin/Rifampin

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of CAD, s/p CABG, and s/p mechanical AVR, who is currently hospitalized for MSSA endocarditis with complications of ARF, AIN, CHB, and torsades. He is now in the ICU with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and hemoptysis, concerning for DAH. The patient has a diffuse rash on his trunk and extremities, which is thought to be leukoclastic dermatitis. The patient's laboratory results show elevated ESR, and the rheumatology team suspects a possible immune-mediated unifying diagnosis, such as vasculitis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory distress and hypoxemia are concerning for DAH, which could be caused by a variety of factors, including pulmonary edema, HAP, or ARDS.
2. Hemoptysis: The patient's hemoptysis could be caused by coagulopathy, vasculitis, or uremic platelets.
3. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's Cr level is trending upward, and the renal team suspects AIN due to Nafcillin. However, it is unclear if this is a manifestation of systemic vasculitis or anti-GBM disease.
4. Leukoclastic Dermatitis: The patient's rash is thought to be due to Nafcillin or IE, but it could also be related to systemic disease causing DAH.
5. Bacteremia: The patient has a high-grade MSSA bacteremia, which fulfills the Duke Criteria for endocarditis.
6. Atrial Fibrillation/Complete Heart Block: The patient has a history of CHB and torsades, and is currently ventricularly pacing with a screw-in pacemaker.
7. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which is thought to be caused by gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. CAD: The patient has a history of CAD and is off anticoagulants due to coagulopathy.
9. s/p AVR: The patient has a history of AVR and is at risk for abscess formation.
10. Hypertension: The patient has hypertension, which is being held due to bleeding.

Treatment Plan:

1. Intubate the patient with a larger tube and initiate bronchoscopy to evaluate for DAH.
2. Run recent medication exposures for possible culprits of DAH.
3. Initiate workup for and treatment of anti-GBM disease, including sending anti-GBM antibody tests and considering plasmapheresis.
4. Consult rheumatology and pathology/pheresis to determine the best course of treatment.
5. Increase steroids to 125 mg Q6h and consider further increasing if recommended by rheumatology.
6. Discuss cyclophosphamide with rheumatology and consider initiating treatment.
7. Hold heparin and protamine, and give vitamin K IV.
8. Broad-spectrum treatment for HAP and send sputum culture.
9. Continue cefazolin for now, but discuss appropriate regimen with ID.
10. Reassess the patient's condition and adjust treatment plan as necessary.

   Assessment and Plan
   76M with CAD s/p CABG, s/p mechanical AVR, Afib; currently hospitalized
   for MSSA endocarditis with complications of ARF and apparent AIN, CHB
   and torsades, and leukocytoclastic dermatitis on skin biopsy, now
   transferred to MICU with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and
   hemoptysis concerning for DAH.
   Concern for immune mediated unifying diagnosis, versus coagulopathy and
   AIN with leukoclastic dermatitis. One critical piece of information may
   be whether immune cells cluster at arterioles in skin (vasculitis) or
   around capillaries (AIN and leukoclastic dermatitis proper). This will
   have important implications for treatment. Anti-GBM antibody test will
   be back tomorrow night at earliest per lab/pathologist. Rheumatology
   feel that this likely represents vasculitis and would like to broaden
   treatment to include plasmaphoresis then Cytoxan therapy. This will
   likely depend on whether pathology and Renal also feel that this is a
   vasculitis, not just AIN with associated rash after nafcillin or
   allopurinol. Goodpasture
s unlikely in view of presentation. ANCA is
   negative, but this is the case in about 20% of Wegener
s cases. No
   dysmorphic reds in urine, but this can sometimes be the case. Possible
   other vasculidites, but IgG, IgM and IgA staining in skin were not
   remarkable.
   # Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure and Possible Vasculitis
   Given findings on CXR, CVP, clinical presentation and bronchoscopy,
   likely secondary to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage and fluid overload. ESR
   is elevated, there is a pupruic macular rash and renal failure, all
   concerning for vasculitis, although there are other possibilities. [**Doctor First Name 1205**]
   and ANCA are negative and anti-GBM is pending. If we seek a unifying
   diagnosis, may be that anti-GBM is negative given skin process.
   Variability in antibody responsible may account for this, and general
   approaches and pathology may eventually be most helpful. Renal biopsy
   is possible (see below). Presently conditions of each organ stabilized
   on high dose steroids, also suggestive. Rheumatology raised Cytoxan
   treatment and plasmaphoresis, but we will need to discuss this further
   with Renal and Pathology.
   - Renal Biopsy this AM
   - Maintain intubation for now given lesser chance of hemorrhage without
   cough and management of respiratory parameters.
   - Await anti-GBM
   - Continue to appreciate input of Rheumatology ,Renal , Derm
   - Continue Solu-medrol
   - sp Renal Biopsy, consider Cytoxan and plasmapheresis with d/w Renal
   and Rheumatology
   - Broad spectrum treatment for HAP
 cefepime and vancomycin
   - Hold heparin, ASA
   - Continue to remove fluid with CVVH
   # Coagulopathy: Plan for Kidney Biopsy today. INR 1.4 this AM,
   Platelets NL however may be dysfunctional given ASA /Uremia.
   - DDAVP today
   - FFP during procedure
   - One unit platlets.
   #. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure
   Cr 1.5 on presentation; up to 3.4, now 1.8 s/p CVVH. DDx includes AIN
   due to Nafcillin (also identical pathophysiology with concomitant rash
 see below).  Now unclear if this is truly manifestation of systemic
   vasculitis or drug reaction. White cells and eosinophils in urine
   consistent with either, although more classic of AIN.
   - f/u renal recs, discuss thoughts re: renal manifestation as above.
   - Renally dose/CVVH dose meds.
   - Management as above, including IV Solu-medrol.
   - Possible renal biopsy tomorrow given that we are now holding
   anticoagulants
   # Leukoclastic Dermatitis
   Thought due to Nafcillin or allopurinol. Improving overall. See
   discussion above for relationship to unifying diagnosis.
   - Steroids as above.
   - FU Derm recommendations
   #. Bacteremia
   High-grade MSSA bacteremia and fulfils Duke Criteria (1 Major, 3 minor)
   for endocarditis. TTE did not reveal vegetations, but sensitivity
   likely low. Nonetheless, given AVR and concern, ID recommend
   antibiotics for a full 8 week course. Switched from Nafcillin/Rifampin
   to Vancomycin [**1-17**] due to question of AIN.
   - Continue to repeat blood cultures.
   - Based on ID input will cover this and possible HAP with vancomycin
   and cefepime.
   # Atrial Fibrillation/Complete Heart Block
   History this admission of CHB (as well as torsades, thought due to
   FQs), now s/p screw-in pacemaker that is presently ventricularly
   pacing.
   - Hold heparin as above, will restart anticoagulation sp biopsy with
   very low ptt goal.
   - EP following - plan for 2 months of this pacer before likely
   permanent pacer.
   # Anemia
   Now with pulmonary hemorrhage likely. If diffuse vasculitis or actually
   secondary to primary coagulopathy then need to maintain suspicion for
   other sites of blood loss, including GIT
   - Recheck Hct Q8.
   - Guaiac stool

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of CAD, s/p CABG, and mechanical AVR, who was admitted for MSSA endocarditis with complications of ARF, AIN, CHB, and torsades, and leukocytoclastic dermatitis on skin biopsy. He was transferred to the MICU with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and hemoptysis concerning for DAH. The patient has a complex medical history, including a recent mechanical AVR, and is currently receiving treatment for endocarditis, ARF, and AIN.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Diffuse Alveolar Hemorrhage (DAH): The patient's respiratory status is critical, and DAH is a potential complication that could worsen his condition.
2. Vasculitis: The patient's skin biopsy shows leukocytoclastic dermatitis, which may be a sign of vasculitis. If confirmed, this could lead to further complications, including organ failure.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's INR is elevated, and he is at risk for bleeding. This could be exacerbated by his anticoagulation therapy.
4. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's Cr is elevated, and he is at risk for further kidney injury.
5. Endocarditis: The patient has a high-grade MSSA bacteremia and fulfills Duke Criteria for endocarditis. This could lead to further complications, including abscess formation and embolization.
6. Atrial Fibrillation/Complete Heart Block: The patient's cardiac status is unstable, and he is at risk for further arrhythmias.
7. Anemia: The patient's Hct is low, and he may be at risk for further bleeding.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's conditions are currently stabilized, but his medical status is critical. The plan is to maintain intubation and mechanical ventilation, and to continue treatment for endocarditis, ARF, and AIN. The patient will undergo a renal biopsy today, and further testing will be done to determine the underlying cause of his vasculitis. The patient's coagulopathy will be managed with DDAVP and FFP, and his anemia will be monitored closely. The patient's cardiac status will be closely monitored, and he will be followed by the EP service.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, mechanical aortic valve replacement, and atrial fibrillation, who was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) endocarditis, acute renal failure, and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). He has been transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to worsening respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and hemoptysis. The patient has a purpuric macular rash on his skin, which is concerning for vasculitis.

The patient has been treated with high-dose steroids, and his condition has been stabilized. However, his respiratory status remains unstable, and he requires mechanical ventilation. His renal function is improving, but he still requires continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT). His coagulopathy is being managed with anticoagulant therapy, and his platelet count is low.

The patient's diagnosis is complex and uncertain, and further testing is needed to determine the underlying cause of his vasculitis and DAH. A renal biopsy is planned to help determine the diagnosis and guide further treatment.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and he may require further interventions, such as tracheostomy or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO), to support his breathing.
2. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy is being managed with anticoagulant therapy, but he may be at risk for bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial hemorrhage.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is improving, but he may still require dialysis or CRRT to manage his kidney function.
4. Endocarditis: The patient has a diagnosis of MSSA endocarditis, and he may require long-term antibiotics to treat this condition.
5. Vasculitis: The patient's vasculitis may be caused by a variety of factors, including autoimmune disorders, infections, or medications. Further testing is needed to determine the underlying cause of his vasculitis and guide further treatment.
6. Leukoclastic dermatitis: The patient has a purpuric macular rash on his skin, which may be a manifestation of his vasculitis or a separate condition. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of his rash and guide further treatment.

In summary, the patient's condition is complex and uncertain, and further testing and treatment are needed to determine the underlying cause of his vasculitis and DAH. Potential medical complications that can arise from his condition include respiratory failure, coagulopathy, renal failure, endocarditis, vasculitis, and leukoclastic dermatitis.

   76M with CAD s/p CABG, s/p mechanical AVR, Afib; currently hospitalized
   for MSSA endocarditis with complications of ARF and apparent AIN, CHB
   and torsades, and leukocytoclastic dermatitis on skin biopsy, now
   transferred to MICU with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and
   hemoptysis concerning for DAH.
   # Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure:
   At this time thought to be secondary to pulmonary edema and
   anticoagulation given negative anti-GBM and rather unrevealing renal
   biopsy. ESR is elevated, there is a pupruic macular rash and renal
   failure, all concerning for vasculitis, although there are other
   possibilities. [**Doctor First Name 1205**] and ANCA are negative. Patient clinically improving
   sp diuresis and steroids. HCT stable.
   - FU Renal Biopsy
   - Maintain intubation for now given lesser chance of hemorrhage without
   cough and management of respiratory parameters.
   - Continue to appreciate input of Rheumatology ,Renal , Derm
   - Broad spectrum treatment for HAP
 cefepime and vancomycin
   - Restart Heparin this AM, no bolus. PTT goal 50-70,
   - Hold ASA until tomorrow
   - Continue to remove fluid with CVVH
   - Continue lower dose steroids at this time.
   .
   #. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure
   Cr 1.5 on presentation; up to 3.4, now 1.6 s/p CVVH. DDx includes AIN
   due to Nafcillin (also identical pathophysiology with concomitant rash
 see below).  Renal biopsy without changes consistent with AIN, may be
   secondary to immune complex deposition in the setting of endocarditis.
   Awaiting immunostaining currently.
   - f/u renal recs, discuss thoughts
   - Renally dose/CVVH dose meds.
   - Lower Dose steroids at this time, however will follow up with renal
   regarding further treatment.
   - FU biopsy results
   # Leukoclastic Dermatitis
   Thought due to Nafcillin or allopurinol. Improving overall. See
   discussion above for relationship to unifying diagnosis.
   - Steroids as above.
   - FU Derm recommendations
   #. Bacteremia
   High-grade MSSA bacteremia and fulfils Duke Criteria (1 Major, 3 minor)
   for endocarditis. TTE did not reveal vegetations, but sensitivity
   likely low. Nonetheless, given AVR and concern, ID recommend
   antibiotics for a full 8 week course. Switched from Nafcillin/Rifampin
   to Vancomycin [**1-17**] due to question of AIN.
   - Continue to repeat blood cultures.
   - Based on ID input will cover this and possible HAP with vancomycin
   and cefepime.
   # Atrial Fibrillation/Complete Heart Block
   History this admission of CHB (as well as torsades, thought due to
   FQs), now s/p screw-in pacemaker that is presently ventricularly
   pacing.
   - restart heparin as above.
   - EP following - plan for 2 months of this pacer before likely
   permanent pacer.
   # Anemia
   Now with pulmonary hemorrhage likely. If diffuse vasculitis or actually
   secondary to primary coagulopathy then need to maintain suspicion for
   other sites of blood loss, including GIT
   - Recheck Hct Q8.
   - Guaiac stool
   - Consented for blood products
   - Maintain access and active type and screen
   - H2 blocker given some concern that PPI could be causing AIN.
   # CAD
   S/p CABG and with DES x3 in one graft. Given coagulopathy, is off
   anticoagulants. [**Month (only) 60**] be some concern for increased thrombosis risk in
   coming days, but have not choice given severity of presentation. We
   will need to revisit this when diagnosis is cleared and natural history
   of this presentation clearer.
   - Continue statin.
   - Hold ASA for until tomorrow, knowing high risk with DES.
   - Holding ACE in the setting of renal failure.
   - Holding BB for now.
   - Heparin as above.
   #. s/p AVR (St. [**Male First Name (un) 6198**]).  Endocarditis as above. Goal for INR [**2-18**], but
   likely higher in this patient given other risks (AF).
   - Heparin as above, transition to coumadin if possible
   - CT surgery consult if clinical condition worsens and concerning for
   abscess.
   - Consider TEE when stabilized and acute issues under control
 patient

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, who was admitted for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) endocarditis, acute kidney injury, and apparent acute interstitial nephritis. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation for respiratory distress and hypoxemia. He has a history of atrial fibrillation, complete heart block, and torsades de pointes, and is currently receiving ventricular pacing.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: Hypoxemic respiratory failure, secondary to pulmonary edema and anticoagulation.
* Renal status: Acute kidney injury, with a creatinine level of 1.6 mg/dL, and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 28.2 mg/dL.
* Hematological status: Anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.2 g/dL, and a platelet count of 263,000/mm3.
* Cardiovascular status: Hypertension, with a blood pressure of 134/62 mmHg, and a heart rate of 75 beats per minute.
* Dermatological status: Leukocytoclastic dermatitis, with a macular non-blanching purpuric rash on the trunk and extremities.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pulmonary hemorrhage: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of pulmonary hemorrhage due to the anticoagulation therapy and the patient's history of bleeding disorders.
2. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and there is a risk of further renal failure due to the ongoing endocarditis and acute kidney injury.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and complete heart block increases the risk of further cardiac arrhythmias, including torsades de pointes.
4. Leukocytoclastic dermatitis: The patient's dermatological condition is concerning, and there is a risk of further skin lesions and systemic complications.
5. Bacteremia: The patient's blood cultures are positive for MSSA, and there is a risk of further bacteremia and endocarditis.

Assessment and plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely, and adjust the ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's anticoagulation therapy, and monitor for signs of bleeding or hemorrhage.
3. Continue to manage the patient's renal status, and monitor for signs of further renal failure.
4. Continue to manage the patient's dermatological condition, and monitor for signs of further skin lesions or systemic complications.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's blood cultures, and adjust the antibiotic therapy as needed.
6. Consider performing a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) to evaluate the patient's cardiac structure and function.
7. Consider consulting with a rheumatologist, nephrologist, and dermatologist to further evaluate the patient's condition and develop a comprehensive treatment plan.

   76M with CAD s/p CABG, s/p mechanical AVR, Afib; currently hospitalized
   for MSSA endocarditis with complications of ARF and apparent AIN, CHB
   and torsades, and leukocytoclastic dermatitis on skin biopsy, now
   transferred to MICU with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and
   hemoptysis concerning for DAH.
   Concern for immune mediated unifying diagnosis, versus coagulopathy and
   AIN with leukoclastic dermatitis. One critical piece of information may
   be whether immune cells cluster at arterioles in skin (vasculitis) or
   around capillaries (AIN and leukoclastic dermatitis proper). This will
   have important implications for treatment. Anti-GBM antibody test will
   be back tomorrow night at earliest per lab/pathologist. Rheumatology
   feel that this likely represents vasculitis and would like to broaden
   treatment to include plasmaphoresis then Cytoxan therapy. This will
   likely depend on whether pathology and Renal also feel that this is a
   vasculitis, not just AIN with associated rash after nafcillin or
   allopurinol. Goodpasture
s unlikely in view of presentation. ANCA is
   negative, but this is the case in about 20% of Wegener
s cases. No
   dysmorphic reds in urine, but this can sometimes be the case. Possible
   other vasculidites, but IgG, IgM and IgA staining in skin were not
   remarkable.
   # Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure and Possible Vasculitis
   Given findings on CXR, CVP, clinical presentation and bronchoscopy,
   likely secondary to diffuse alveolar hemorrhage and fluid overload. ESR
   is elevated, there is a pupruic macular rash and renal failure, all
   concerning for vasculitis, although there are other possibilities. [**Doctor First Name 1205**]
   and ANCA are negative and anti-GBM is pending. If we seek a unifying
   diagnosis, may be that anti-GBM is negative given skin process.
   Variability in antibody responsible may account for this, and general
   approaches and pathology may eventually be most helpful. Renal biopsy
   is possible (see below). Presently conditions of each organ stabilized
   on high dose steroids, also suggestive. Rheumatology raised Cytoxan
   treatment and plasmaphoresis, but we will need to discuss this further
   with Renal and Pathology.
   - Renal Biopsy this AM
   - Maintain intubation for now given lesser chance of hemorrhage without
   cough and management of respiratory parameters.
   - Await anti-GBM
   - Continue to appreciate input of Rheumatology ,Renal , Derm
   - Continue Solu-medrol
   - sp Renal Biopsy, consider Cytoxan and plasmapheresis with d/w Renal
   and Rheumatology
   - Broad spectrum treatment for HAP
 cefepime and vancomycin
   - Hold heparin, ASA
   - Continue to remove fluid with CVVH
   # Coagulopathy: Plan for Kidney Biopsy today. INR 1.4 this AM,
   Platelets NL however may be dysfunctional given ASA /Uremia.
   - DDAVP today
   - FFP during procedure
   - One unit platlets.
   #. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure
   Cr 1.5 on presentation; up to 3.4, now 1.8 s/p CVVH. DDx includes AIN
   due to Nafcillin (also identical pathophysiology with concomitant rash
 see below).  Now unclear if this is truly manifestation of systemic
   vasculitis or drug reaction. White cells and eosinophils in urine

   - Steroids as above.

   #. Bacteremia
   High-grade MSSA bacteremia and fulfils Duke Criteria (1 Major, 3 minor)
   for endocarditis. TTE did not reveal vegetations, but sensitivity
   likely low. Nonetheless, given AVR and concern, ID recommend

   and cefepime.

   History this admission of CHB (as well as torsades, thought due to

   pacing.
   - Hold heparin as above, will restart anticoagulation sp biopsy with

   secondary to primary coagulopathy then need to maintain suspicion for
   other sites of blood loss, including GIT

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of CAD, s/p CABG, and s/p mechanical AVR, who is currently hospitalized for MSSA endocarditis with complications of ARF, AIN, CHB, and leukocytoclastic dermatitis. He is now transferred to the MICU with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and hemoptysis, concerning for DAH. The patient's condition is complex and multifaceted, with potential medical complications including:

1. Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, with a high risk of further deterioration.
2. Vasculitis: The patient's presentation is concerning for vasculitis, with evidence of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, elevated ESR, and a purpuric macular rash.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy, with an INR of 1.4 and platelets that may be dysfunctional.
4. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient has a high-grade MSSA bacteremia and fulfills Duke Criteria for endocarditis, with a high risk of further renal deterioration.
5. Leukoclastic Dermatitis: The patient has a rash consistent with leukoclastic dermatitis, which may be related to Nafcillin or allopurinol.
6. Bacteremia: The patient has a high-grade MSSA bacteremia, which requires continued antibiotic treatment.
7. Atrial Fibrillation/Complete Heart Block: The patient has a history of CHB and torsades, which is now being managed with a ventricularly pacing pacemaker.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely secondary to pulmonary hemorrhage, and further evaluation is needed to rule out other sites of blood loss.
9. CAD: The patient's CAD is a risk factor for increased thrombosis, and anticoagulation therapy is being withheld due to the patient's coagulopathy.
10. s/p AVR: The patient has a history of s/p AVR, which may be related to his endocarditis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

* Further respiratory deterioration
* Worsening of vasculitis
* Increased risk of bleeding due to coagulopathy
* Further renal deterioration
* Increased risk of infection due to bacteremia
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Anemia
* Increased risk of thrombosis
* Abscess formation
* Septic shock

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* High-dose steroids
* Plasmapheresis
* Cytoxan therapy
* Broad-spectrum antibiotics
* CVVH
* DDAVP
* FFP
* One unit of platelets
* H2 blocker
* Statin
* Holding ASA and ACE
* Holding heparin
* Monitoring for signs of bleeding and infection
* Close monitoring of renal function and electrolyte levels
* Regular blood cultures and respiratory support
* Consideration of renal biopsy and TEE

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of CAD, s/p CABG, s/p mechanical AVR, and Afib, currently hospitalized for MSSA endocarditis with complications of ARF, AIN, CHB, and torsades. He is now transferred to the MICU with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and hemoptysis concerning for DAH. The patient has a complex medical history, with multiple comorbidities and ongoing treatments.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's respiratory distress and hypoxemia may be secondary to pulmonary edema, which can be caused by various factors such as fluid overload, cardiac failure, or medication side effects.
2. Vasculitis: The patient's elevated ESR, purpuric macular rash, and renal failure are concerning for vasculitis, although the diagnosis is not yet confirmed.
3. Atrial Fibrillation/Complete Heart Block: The patient's history of Afib and CHB, as well as his current ventricularly pacing, may increase his risk of cardiac complications.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be secondary to pulmonary hemorrhage, diffuse vasculitis, or primary coagulopathy.
5. Endocarditis: The patient's MSSA endocarditis may lead to further complications such as valve damage, abscess formation, or embolization.
6. Renal Failure: The patient's ARF may progress to chronic renal failure if not properly managed.
7. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's hemoptysis and anemia may indicate gastrointestinal bleeding, which can be life-threatening.
8. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may increase his risk of bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding and pulmonary hemorrhage.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust treatment as necessary to manage pulmonary edema.
2. Consider further evaluation for vasculitis, including immunostaining and renal biopsy.
3. Continue anticoagulation therapy with heparin and consider transitioning to coumadin if possible.
4. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusions as necessary.
5. Continue antibiotic therapy for endocarditis and consider adding antifungal therapy if necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust treatment as necessary to manage ARF.
7. Consider endoscopy or other diagnostic tests to evaluate the patient's gastrointestinal tract and identify any potential bleeding sources.
8. Monitor the patient's coagulopathy and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent bleeding complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, mechanical aortic valve replacement, atrial fibrillation, and recent diagnosis of MSSA endocarditis. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and hemoptysis, concerning for diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH).

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and creatinine, indicating active infection and kidney damage. His coagulation profile is abnormal, with elevated international normalized ratio (INR) and partial thromboplastin time (PTT), suggesting disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

The patient's physical examination reveals bilateral expiratory rhonchi and coarse crackles, indicating respiratory distress, as well as a diffuse rash over the trunk and extremities, which is consistent with leukocytoclastic dermatitis.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Broad-spectrum antibiotics for MSSA endocarditis and possible hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).
2. Restarting heparin therapy to prevent further thrombosis and DIC.
3. Maintaining intubation and mechanical ventilation to support respiratory function.
4. Continuing CVVH to remove fluid and waste products.
5. Lower-dose steroids to reduce inflammation and prevent further organ damage.
6. Repeated blood cultures to monitor for bacteremia.
7. Electrolyte repletion and correction of acid-base imbalance.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Further respiratory distress and hypoxemia, potentially leading to respiratory failure.
2. Increased bleeding risk due to coagulopathy and platelet dysfunction.
3. Renal failure and acute kidney injury, potentially requiring dialysis.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias and heart block, potentially requiring pacemaker implantation.
5. Infection and sepsis, potentially leading to multi-organ dysfunction.
6. Neurological complications, such as seizures and stroke, potentially due to DIC or endocarditis.

To address these potential complications, the patient's care team should:

1. Monitor the patient's respiratory function closely and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Closely monitor the patient's coagulation profile and adjust heparin therapy accordingly.
3. Repeatedly assess the patient's renal function and adjust fluid management and electrolyte repletion accordingly.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust pacemaker settings as needed.
5. Repeatedly assess the patient's neurological status and address any potential complications promptly.
6. Repeatedly assess the patient's infection status and adjust antibiotic therapy accordingly.

Overall, the patient's complex medical condition requires close monitoring and multidisciplinary care to prevent further complications and ensure optimal outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of CAD, s/p CABG and mechanical AVR, who was admitted with MSSA endocarditis and complications of ARF, AIN, CHB, and torsades. He was transferred to the MICU with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and hemoptysis, concerning for DAH. The patient's condition has been improving, with stabilization of his renal function and hemoglobin levels. He is currently intubated and receiving ventilation, and his secretions have decreased.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains critical, with ongoing respiratory distress and hypoxemia. He is at risk for further deterioration and may require continued intubation and ventilation.
2. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient has ongoing hemoptysis and hematuria, which may be secondary to coagulopathy or vasculitis. He is at risk for further bleeding and may require close monitoring and treatment.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal function remains compromised, with ongoing need for dialysis and potential for further deterioration.
4. Infectious complications: The patient has ongoing bacteremia and endocarditis, which may require continued antibiotics and monitoring for signs of sepsis.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of CAD and has undergone CABG and mechanical AVR. He is at risk for further cardiac complications, including increased thrombosis risk, and may require close monitoring and treatment.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's hematuria and ongoing bleeding may be secondary to gastrointestinal bleeding, which may require close monitoring and treatment.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's mental status is lightly sedated, and he may be at risk for further neurological deterioration.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to closely monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation and oxygenation as needed.
2. Continue to treat the patient's bacteremia and endocarditis with antibiotics and monitor for signs of sepsis.
3. Continue to manage the patient's coagulopathy with heparin and other anticoagulants as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust dialysis and other treatments as needed.
5. Consider further imaging studies, such as echocardiogram and CT scans, to further evaluate the patient's cardiovascular and gastrointestinal status.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust sedation and other treatments as needed.
7. Consider consultation with specialists, such as cardiology, nephrology, and gastroenterology, to further evaluate and manage the patient's complex medical condition.

   Assessment and Plan
   76M with CAD s/p CABG, s/p mechanical AVR, Afib; currently hospitalized
   for MSSA endocarditis with complications of ARF and apparent AIN, CHB
   and torsades, and leukocytoclastic dermatitis on skin biopsy, now
   transferred to MICU with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and
   hemoptysis concerning for DAH.
   # DAH/Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure/Ventilation/Intubation
   Maintain intubation and ventilation for now given continued secretions
   during the day yesterday. Secretions had improved throughout the night,
   and can consider extubation later this pm. Hypoxemic respiratory
   failure has largely resolved - was likely due to pulmonary edema and
   diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. The etiology of hemorrhage is unclear.
   Differential diagnoses include vasculitic and autoimmune processes,
   coagulopathy, or the effect of pulmonary edema in the context of
   coagulopathy. Vaculitis was initially thought most likely, given renal
   failure, rash and pulmonary hemorrhage, but investigations for this
   have been relatively unimpressive: ESR from 15 to 100s now, but
   negative [**Doctor First Name 1205**], ANCA, anti-GBM and unimpressive pathology of skin and
   kidney, although the final read of the latter is pending. Patient
   clinically improving s/p diuresis and steroids and HCT stable.
   Vasculitis now unlikely enough to taper steroids to level for treatment
   of AIN along. Nonetheless, ANCA may not be positive in early disease
   and should be repeated in three to four weeks. Possibility of worsened
   MR and pulmonary edema, but unlikely given echo three days ago.
   - Continue to follow up renal biopsy results from [**1-29**]
   - SBT and consider extubation this PM given improved secretions and
   lesser chance of hemorrhage without cough and management of respiratory
   parameters
   - Continue to appreciate input of Rheumatology (want to taper
   steroids), Renal (steroids for AIN only), Dermatology (topical
   steroid).
   - Continue broad spectrum treatment for HAP, MSSA bacteremia in context
   of AVR
 Cefepime and Vancomycin
   - Continue Heparin gtt with PTT goal 50-70
   - Hold ASA for now given bloody secretions; can likely restart today
   - Continue to remove fluid with CVVH
   - Continue Prednisone 30mg to treat AIN (will check with Renal, but
   likely will need for 4 weeks; start date [**2-1**])
   #. Hemoptysis
   Discussion above pertains. Likely little further benefit and possible
   harm, so hold bronchoscopy for now.
   #. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure/AIN
   Cr 1.5 on presentation; up to 3.4, now 1.2 on CVVH. DDx includes AIN
   due to Nafcillin (also identical pathophysiology with concomitant rash
 see below), although Allopurinol and Warfarin can also less
   frequently (and much less likely in this case) produce this effect.
   Renal biopsy without changes consistent with AIN, but already given a
   few days of high-dose steroids. Awaiting final renal pathology results
   and evaluation. Evidence for AIN includes white cell casts, worsened
   renal function and urinary eosinophils.
   - Continue Prednisone 30mg to treat AIN (will check with Renal, but
   likely will need for 4 weeks; start date [**2-1**])
   - Continue to renally dose medications
   - Continue to remove fluid with CVVH
   - Continue to follow up renal biopsy results from [**1-29**]
   - Continue to follow urine output
   - Continue to follow Renal recommendations
   #. Hematuria
   Likely secondary to biopsy in context of said coagulopathy. Will need
   to monitor given danger period following biopsy is about two weeks.
   Likely too bloody for vasculitic cause.
   - Ask Renal if benefit to spinning when so frankly bloody (surely not
   just due to vasculitis given amount, precipitant (biopsy), and no
   vasculitis on biopsy) (also send UA but may not be helpful for the same
   reason).
   - Continue to follow urine output and if hematuria
   - Consider irrigation if reduction in urine output, suprapubic pain or
   residual volume
   # Leukoclastic Dermatitis
   Is recovering. Thought to be due to Nafcillin or Allopurinol
 case
   reports of Warfarin also, but much less likely. Improving overall. See
   discussion above for relationship to unifying diagnosis.
   - Continue steroids as above.
   - Continue to follow Derm recommendations
   #. Bacteremia
   High-grade MSSA bacteremia and fulfils Duke Criteria (1 Major, 3 minor)
   for endocarditis. TTE did not reveal vegetations, but sensitivity
   likely low. Nonetheless, given AVR and concern, ID recommends
   antibiotics for a full 8 week course. Switched from Nafcillin/Rifampin
   to Vancomycin [**1-17**] due to question of AIN.
   - Continue to repeat blood cultures
   - Continue broad spectrum treatment for HAP, MSSA bacteremia in context
   of AVR
 Cefepime and Vancomycin
   - Continue to follow ID recommendations
   # Atrial Fibrillation/Complete Heart Block
   History this admission of CHB (as well as torsades, thought due to
   FQs), now s/p screw-in pacemaker that is presently ventricularly
   pacing.
   - Continue Heparin as above
   - EP following - plan for 2 months of this pacer before likely
   permanent pacer.
   # Anemia
   Hematocrit has been stable. Now with pulmonary hemorrhage likely. If
   diffuse vasculitis or actually secondary to primary coagulopathy then
   need to maintain suspicion for other sites of blood loss, including GI
   tract. Patient is consented for blood products.
   - Continue to check Hematocrit q8
   - Guaiac stool
   - Continue to maintain active T&S
   - Continue Protonix while being aware that PPI may also cause AIN
   # CAD
   S/p CABG and with DES x3 in one graft. Given coagulopathy, is off
   anticoagulants. [**Month (only) 60**] be some concern for increased thrombosis risk in
   coming days, but have not choice given severity of presentation. We
   will need to revisit this when diagnosis is cleared and natural history
   of this presentation clearer.
   - Continue statin
   - Hold ASA for now given bloody secretions; can likely restart today
   - Holding ACE in the setting of renal failure
   - Holding BB for now
   - Continue Heparin as above

   likely higher in this patient given other risks (AF).
   - Heparin as above, transition to coumadin if possible
   - CT surgery consult if clinical condition worsens and concerning for
   abscess.
   - Consider TEE when stabilized and acute issues under control

   #. Mental Status
   Lightly sedated. Will lighten slightly further today.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, mechanical aortic valve replacement, atrial fibrillation, and acute on chronic renal failure. The patient is currently hospitalized for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) endocarditis with complications of acute renal failure, apparent acute interstitial nephritis (AIN), and leukocytoclastic dermatitis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and ventilated due to hypoxemic respiratory failure and hemoptysis. The secretions have improved, and the patient may be considered for extubation later in the day.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a mechanical aortic valve and is at risk for endocarditis. The patient is receiving anticoagulation therapy with heparin, and the goal PTT is 50-60.
* Renal: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure and is receiving continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT). The patient's creatinine level has improved from 1.5 to 1.2.
* Hematological: The patient has anemia and is receiving blood products. The patient's hematocrit level is stable.
* Skin: The patient has a rash consistent with leukocytoclastic dermatitis, which is thought to be secondary to Nafcillin or Allopurinol.
* Neurological: The patient is lightly sedated and has a normal mental status.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH): The patient's hemoptysis and pulmonary edema may indicate DAH, which can be life-threatening.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's renal function is already compromised, and further AKI may occur due to nephrotoxic medications or sepsis.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's bleeding complications and low platelet count may indicate a coagulopathy, which can increase the risk of bleeding and thrombosis.
4. Infection: The patient has MSSA bacteremia and endocarditis, which can lead to sepsis and organ failure.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's mechanical aortic valve and atrial fibrillation may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as thromboembolism and heart failure.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and bleeding complications may indicate gastrointestinal bleeding, which can be life-threatening.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continue intubation and ventilation for now.
2. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics for MSSA bacteremia and endocarditis.
3. Continue anticoagulation therapy with heparin.
4. Continue CRRT for renal failure.
5. Continue steroids for AIN and leukocytoclastic dermatitis.
6. Monitor the patient's renal function and electrolyte levels.
7. Consider extubation and weaning from mechanical ventilation once the patient's secretions have improved.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and improve outcomes.

   76M with CAD s/p CABG, s/p mechanical AVR, Afib; currently hospitalized
   for MSSA endocarditis with complications of ARF and apparent AIN, CHB
   and torsades, and leukocytoclastic dermatitis on skin biopsy, now
   transferred to MICU with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and
   hemoptysis concerning for DAH.
   # DAH/Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure/Ventilation/Intubation
   Maintain intubation and ventilation for now given continued secretions
   during the day yesterday. Secretions had improved throughout the night,
   and can consider extubation later this pm. Hypoxemic respiratory
   failure has largely resolved - was likely due to pulmonary edema and
   diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. The etiology of hemorrhage is unclear.
   Differential diagnoses include vasculitic and autoimmune processes,
   coagulopathy, or the effect of pulmonary edema in the context of
   coagulopathy. Vaculitis was initially thought most likely, given renal
   failure, rash and pulmonary hemorrhage, but investigations for this
   have been relatively unimpressive: ESR from 15 to 100s now, but
   negative [**Doctor First Name 1205**], ANCA, anti-GBM and unimpressive pathology of skin and
   kidney, although the final read of the latter is pending. Patient
   clinically improving s/p diuresis and steroids and HCT stable.
   Vasculitis now unlikely enough to taper steroids to level for treatment
   of AIN along. Nonetheless, ANCA may not be positive in early disease
   and should be repeated in three to four weeks. Possibility of worsened
   MR and pulmonary edema, but unlikely given echo three days ago.
   - Continue to follow up renal biopsy results from [**1-29**]
   - SBT and consider extubation this PM given improved secretions and
   lesser chance of hemorrhage without cough and management of respiratory
   parameters
   - Continue to appreciate input of Rheumatology (want to taper
   steroids), Renal (steroids for AIN only), Dermatology (topical
   steroid).

 Cefepime and Vancomycin

   - Plan to discontinue CVVH

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of CAD, s/p CABG, and s/p mechanical AVR, who is currently hospitalized for MSSA endocarditis with complications of ARF, AIN, CHB, and torsades, and leukocytoclastic dermatitis on skin biopsy. The patient has been transferred to the MICU due to respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and hemoptysis concerning for DAH.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 75 bpm, and blood pressure of 108/46 mmHg. The patient is intubated and ventilated, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 338.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 20.9 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 34.2%
* Platelet count: 317
* Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 18 mg/dL
* Glucose: 162 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* LDH: 333 IU/L
* Calcium: 9.2 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.5 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.4 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Intubated and moderately sedated
* Draining thin secretions from the lung that are moderately blood-tinged
* Bilateral expiratory rhonchi and coarse crackles
* Regular normal S1 and S2 heart sounds
* Soft, non-tender, non-distended abdomen
* Warm, well-perfused extremities with dry skin
* Non-blanching rash over the lower extremities
* Sedated but rousable and able to interact meaningfully

The patient's diagnosis includes:

* DAH
* Hypoxemic respiratory failure
* Ventilation
* Intubation
* ARF
* AIN
* CHB
* Torsades
* Leukocytoclastic dermatitis
* MSSA endocarditis
* Bacteremia
* Atrial fibrillation
* Complete heart block

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continue intubation and ventilation for now
* Continue steroids for AIN
* Continue Heparin with a PTT goal of 50-70
* Continue broad-spectrum treatment for HAP and MSSA bacteremia
* Continue to follow up renal biopsy results
* Continue to follow up on blood cultures
* Consider extubation later this pm if secretions improve
* Plan to discontinue CVVH
* Continue to monitor for signs of bleeding and coagulopathy

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening of respiratory failure
* Development of pneumonia
* Hemorrhagic shock
* Coagulopathy
* Thrombosis
* Endocarditis
* Bacteremia
* Sepsis
* Renal failure
* AIN
* Leukocytoclastic dermatitis

The patient's code status is full code, and their disposition is pending clinical improvement.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of CAD, s/p CABG, and s/p mechanical AVR, admitted with MSSA bacteremia, torsades, and ARF likely secondary to AIN. He was previously on CVVH and is now being managed with HD. The patient has a petechial rash on his lower extremities, which is improving. He has been extubated and is stable off of positive pressure ventilation. The patient's labs show worsening renal function, with increasing BUN, Cr, and HCO3 levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening Renal Function: The patient's BUN, Cr, and HCO3 levels are increasing, suggesting worsening renal function. This may lead to further fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and acid-base disturbances.
2. Flash Pulmonary Edema: The patient's fluid overload and worsening renal function may lead to flash pulmonary edema, which can be life-threatening.
3. Hemorrhagic Complications: The patient's bleeding diathesis and history of DAH/Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure/Ventilation/Intubation/Hemoptysis may lead to further bleeding complications, including GI bleeding, intracranial bleeding, or pulmonary bleeding.
4. Infection: The patient's MSSA bacteremia and ongoing antibiotic therapy may lead to the development of antibiotic-resistant bacteria or the emergence of new pathogens.
5. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of CAD, s/p CABG, and s/p mechanical AVR, as well as his current anticoagulation therapy, may lead to cardiac complications, including arrhythmias, congestive heart failure, or cardiac tamponade.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient's bleeding diathesis and history of torsades may lead to neurological complications, including seizures, stroke, or intracranial bleeding.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of DAH/Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure/Ventilation/Intubation/Hemoptysis and ongoing anticoagulation therapy may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.
8. Respiratory Complications: The patient's ongoing respiratory failure and history of DAH/Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure/Ventilation/Intubation/Hemoptysis may lead to further respiratory complications, including respiratory failure, pneumonia, or acute respiratory distress syndrome.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust therapy accordingly.
2. Monitor the patient's fluid status and adjust fluid administration to prevent further fluid overload.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding diathesis and adjust anticoagulation therapy as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy accordingly.
5. Consider consulting with cardiothoracic surgery for further management of the patient's cardiac complications.
6. Consider consulting with neurology for further management of the patient's neurological complications.
7. Consider consulting with gastroenterology for further management of the patient's gastrointestinal complications.
8. Continue to follow up with the patient's primary care physician and other specialists as necessary.

   2 days and seems to be stable off of positive pressure from ventilator.
   Concern for flash pulmonary edema during this period
 can plan to
   restart CVVH or emergent HD pending renal recommendations today should
   such an event occur. Hypoxemic respiratory failure has largely resolved
   - was likely due to pulmonary edema and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage.
   The etiology of hemorrhage is unclear and likely multifactorial.
   Differential diagnoses include vasculitic and autoimmune processes,

   coagulopathy. Vaculitis was initially thought most likely, given renal
   failure, rash and pulmonary hemorrhage, but investigations for this

   negative [**Doctor First Name 1205**], ANCA, anti-GBM and unimpressive pathology of skin and

   clinically improving s/p diuresis and steroids and HCT stable.
   Vasculitis now unlikely enough to taper steroids to level for treatment
   of AIN along. Nonetheless, ANCA may not be positive in early disease
   and should be repeated in three to four weeks. Possibility of worsened
   MR and pulmonary edema, but unlikely given echo three days ago.
